On a lonely selection far out in the West,
Where the silence is thick as a woolen coat,
A radio whispers in Morse code, obsessed
With calling a name that no longer takes note.

It crackles each dusk, when the voltage runs low,
Spelling out "Ella" in dots and in dashes.
No hand ever turned it on, no one to know
If the voice in the static is hers or just ashes.

The house is long roofless, the wires all frayed,
Yet the signal persists through the dry, aching air.
It hums through the grass, where the rabbits are laid,
And glows in the eyes of a goat standing there.

Some say it’s the soul of a man who stayed
To listen for answers that never came through.
He starved at the set, as the signals decayed,
But his spirit still sends what he never withdrew.

Now the stars seem to blink in the same rhythmic code,
As if answering back from a faraway place.
And the wind carries whispers along the old road—
A language of loss, of enduring embrace.

On a lonely selection far out in the West,
Where the trees stand like judges with arms folded tight,
A piano once played without anyone pressed,
Its keys rising slow in the pale morning light.

No hand touched the ivories, no foot worked the damper,
Yet nocturnes would rise with the dew and the frost.
Locals said it was haunted by a young scamper
Who died in the fire that the lightning had cost.

Her father had bought it to prove he was grand,
But she never learned, too shy, too afraid.
Now her ghost plays the songs she could never command,
In a language the wind has since learned to evade.

The roof has collapsed, and the hutch is exposed,
Keys yellowed, the felt torn by mice and the years.
Yet on nights when the moon is both pale and composed,
Music drifts—soft, uninvited—through tears.

A stockman once swore he saw shadows align,
A girl at the bench, her hair in a braid.
She played for the stars, for the dirt, for the brine
Of a heart that still dreams, though its body decayed.

On a lonely selection far out in the West,
Where the sun carves the hills into amber and rust,
A poet once tried to capture the zest
Of silence so deep it could swallow one’s trust.

He brought ink and quills, notebooks bound in hide,
Set up camp by a billabong cracked and forlorn.
But no words came—just the wind’s endless tide,
And the buzz of a fly at the edge of the morn.

He stayed for a season, then burned every page,
Watched the ash swirl upward like dark, fleeing birds.
He left no farewell, no final stage,
Just footprints erased by the hoofbeats of herds.

Now, when the air is as still as a breath,
You might hear a whisper beneath the gum trees—
Not words, but the ghost of the struggle with death
Of a man who sought truth on his knees.

And some say the wind carries syllables torn
From poems that never were written or read,
A lament for the moment creativity’s born,
Only to die where no one treads.

On a lonely selection far out in the West,
Where the soil drinks its fill from the bones of the past,
A garden once bloomed in a defiant bequest,
Of roses and mint that were never meant to last.

A woman planted them, seed by rare seed,
Watered with bottles she carried each day.
Her husband had scoffed, said the effort would bleed
Into dust, like all dreams that resist disarray.

But she knelt in the dirt, her hands cracked and red,
And sang to the stems in a low, crooning tone.
The roses grew pale, but they bloomed nonetheless,
And the mint spread like hope through the hard, broken stone.

He left in the winter, took the horse and the name,
But she stayed with the flowers, the bees, and the thorn.
Years passed. The garden outlived all her shame,
And the roses still bloom—though she’s long since been gone.

Now travelers pick one, then hesitate, drop it—
For the petals are cold, and the scent is not sweet,
But carries the weight of a love that won’t stop it,
And a woman who knelt where the wild things meet.

On a lonely selection far out in the West,
Where the dawns come in silence and leave without noise,
A boy once believed he could fly with the rest
Of the hawks that circled above the dry poise.

He stitched wings from canvas and chicken wire,
Stole feathers from pillows and parrots long dead.
He leapt from the shed at the break of dayfire,
And crashed in the dust, with a voice full of dread.

His mother cried once, then said no more words,
Just bandaged his arms and swept up the debris.
She knew this land crushed all who dreamed like the birds,
And prayed he’d grow dull, like the rest of the free.

But each spring, he tried, with new threads, new design,
Till his body grew frail from the falls and the pain.
Then one morning, no crash, no cry, no sign—

On a lonely selection far out in the West,
Where the night holds its breath in a vacuum of sound,
A lantern still burns in a window’s bare nest,
Though the house fell to ruin a hundred years down.

No hand lights the wick, no oil feeds the flame,
Yet it glows through the dark with a steady, soft gold.
It flickers at dawn, then returns just the same,
As if waiting for someone too lost to be told.

They say it belongs to a mother who stayed,
While her boys rode off to the war and the south.
She lit it each night, in the dark, unafraid,
But they never came back—no word, no mouth.

She died in the chair, her eyes facing the road,
But the lantern kept burning, defiant, alone.
Now travelers stop, leave a stone, lift their load,
And whisper the names they still carry, unknown.

And sometimes, when grief is too heavy to hold,
The flame burns more brightly, as if in reply—
A light in the void, more precious than gold,
That says, "I am here," to the vast, starless sky.

On a lonely selection far out in the West,
Where the rivers are maps of what used to be,
A fisherman cast in a drought-stricken vest,
For a trout that had vanished, as legends decree.

He came every dawn with his rod made of yew,
Sat by the crack in the riverbed’s skin.
No water, no shadow, no glint in the view—
Just heat and the buzz of the locust within.

Yet he cast anyway, with a flick of the wrist,
Reeled in the air, spoke to fish long gone.
"I’ll catch you tomorrow," he softly would hiss,
Though tomorrow kept passing, and no fish drawn.

His hat grew a halo of dust and of age,
His boots turned to fossils, his voice to a hum.
But he stayed, like a prophet on a dry, wide stage,
Until one day, silence became his drum.

Now his shadow remains by the dry riverbank,
Rod raised in salute to a stream made of sky.
And some say that, if you just pause and you think,
You’ll hear the soft splash as the trout swims on by.

The page is still fed, the 'Q' key stuck down,

No author returned, no one claimed the lost sound
Of the words left unfinished, suspended in air.

It typed through the nights, keys clacking like bones,
Writing confessions the owner denied.
Of love for a swagman, of stones in the lungs,
Of the child in the well that the wind never cried.

But the writer fled, couldn’t face what was spelled,
Left the machine clicking its truth into night.
Now it types on alone, a story compelled,
Of guilt, of the land, of the will to take flight.

And when travelers pass, they pause at the sound—
A rhythm of secrets too raw to be known.
The typewriter writes, and the words pile up round,
A monument built from the flesh and the bone.

instance_metrics.response:
Everyone has a fear, a shadow that clings,
A whisper in silence where dread softly sings.
It coils in the chest when the lights flicker low,
A secret the heart has long learned how to stow.
For some, it’s the dark, the void without sound,
Where echoes of footsteps make reason unbound.
For others, the crowd, the crush of the face,
A sea of eyes stealing warmth, stealing grace.
A child fears monsters beneath the bed’s rim,
While elders fear silence, the world growing dim.
The artist fears blankness, the void on the page,
The lover fears silence after a rage.
Even the brave nurse a tremor inside,
A crack in their courage they tightly hide.
But fear is not evil, nor weakness to scorn,
It’s proof we are human, that we’re not reborn
Without doubt, without risk, without trembling breath—
It’s the price we pay for the dance with life and death.
So cradle your fear, let it speak, let it stay,
For courage is not fear’s absence—but its sway.

So greet your old shadow, let your breath slow and clear—
Everyone has a fear, but none need live here.

instance_metrics.response:
O God! Thou art my God alone;
In shadowed vale or mountain throne,
Thy presence is the dawn's first light,
The hush that follows through the night.
Not gold nor kingdom, fame nor song,
Can match the peace for which I long—
To dwell within Thy secret grace,
Where time dissolves and breath slows pace.
I seek Thee in the wind’s soft moan,
O God! Thou art my God alone.

Thy voice, a flame in winter’s bone,
A whispered hymn in blood and stone.
No idol carved by human hand,
Can stand where Thou, unseen, dost stand.
When stars grow dim and oceans groan,
I call: O God! Thou art my God alone!

Even in doubt, I kneel, unknown,
Yet known by Thee, and not alone.
For in the silence, breath has grown
A psalm—my heart, Thy living stone.
So let the ages rise and fall,
My soul shall heed no other call:
O God! Thou art my God alone,
My end, my breath, my coming home.

Not science cold, nor art’s soft tone,

No lover’s kiss, no battle won,

Can fill the void I’ve always known—
Only Thy breath, my life, my own.
O God! Thou art my God alone.

Lit fires where demons used to hide,
But only when the flames were gone,
Did I hear Thee say: You are not wrong.
No creed, no cult, no sacred tone,
No priestly chant, no gilded throne,
Can match the truth I’ve overgrown:
O God! Thou art my God alone.

Let every idol fall and groan,
Let every false god stand dethroned—
This heart, once lost, now clearly known,
Sings one refrain, and one alone:
O God! Thou art my God alone.

instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'O God! Thou art my God alone;'

instance_metrics.response:
Rewind life and remember—
threads of time unspool like silver ribbon,
looping through childhood’s amber light,
where laughter dripped from porch swings,
and fireflies held secrets in their glow.
I walk backward through seasons,
feet retracing barefoot summers,
finding the girl who believed in magic,
in dandelion wishes and sidewalk chalk dreams.
Each frame flickers: first heartbreak,
the hush before a father’s last breath,
the kiss that tasted like forever.
But rewinding isn’t healing—
it’s a ghostly cinema,
playing what can’t be changed.
Still, I linger in moments
where joy outweighed sorrow,
where love was loud and unafraid.
I remember the scent of rain on hot pavement,
the weight of a dog’s head on my knee,
the way music once moved my bones.
Rewind life and remember—
not to alter the script,
but to reclaim the echo,
to whisper to my past self:
You were seen. You were whole.
And in remembering, I stitch
the frayed edges of now
with golden thread from then.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'rewind life and remember'

instance_metrics.response:
Rewind life and remember—
the phrase hums like an old cassette,
its magnetic tape worn thin
from too many replays.
I press play in reverse,
watching snow fall upward,
broken plates reassemble on the kitchen floor,
words I regret sucked back into my mouth.
I float through inverted days:
my first step becomes a crawl,
then a wail in the sterile light of birth.
I see my mother’s face—
young, tired, radiant—
holding me like a promise.
I remember the cat that vanished,
the friendship I let drift,
the poem I never sent.
Time, rewound, isn’t kind;
it shows all I failed to hold.
But in the silence between beats,
I hear a lullaby,
feel the phantom warmth of hands
long turned to dust.
Rewind life and remember—
it’s not about fixing,
but forgiving.
Forgiving myself
for being human,
for choosing wrong,
for living too fast to notice.
Now, I press pause,
not to stay in the past,
but to carry its quiet wisdom forward,
like a candle lit in a storm.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'rewind life and remember'

instance_metrics.response:
Rewind life and remember—
like a film spooling in reverse,
I see the endings before the beginnings,
funerals before births,
goodbyes before hellos.
The river flows uphill,
carrots rise from the soil into my palm,
and tears retreat into eyes, unshed.
I am pulled backward through decades,
watching wrinkles smooth,
hair darken, bones lighten.
I remember being small enough
to fit in my father’s shadow,
to believe the moon followed me home.
I remember the dog who waited
every afternoon at the bus stop,
tail wagging like a metronome.
But rewinding reveals pain too:
the slow unraveling of a parent’s mind,
the silence after a slammed door,
the love that faded like old photographs.
Yet memory, even in reverse,
holds a strange grace.
It whispers: you were loved,
even when you didn’t know it.
You mattered,
even in your smallest moments.
Rewind life and remember—
not to escape the present,
but to honor the journey,
to gather the scattered pieces
and say: I was here.
And that is enough.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'rewind life and remember'

instance_metrics.response:
Rewind life and remember—
the command echoes in the hollows
of a mind grown dusty with years.
I twist the dial of time,
feel the world stutter and spin,
like a record played backward.
Voices slur into prophecy,
smiles form before the joke is told.
I watch myself grow younger,
not in body, but in spirit—
reclaiming wonder,
the awe of a spider’s web jeweled with dew,
the thrill of a first bike ride.
I remember the scent of my grandmother’s kitchen,
cinnamon and sorrow braided in her bread.
I remember the boy who kissed me
beneath a sky full of stars,
and how I didn’t know it would be the last.
Rewinding, I see the choices
like branching paths in reverse:
the job I didn’t take,
the letter I never wrote,
the moment I walked away.
But time’s reversal isn’t control—
it’s clarity.
It shows me what I cherished,
what I overlooked,
what I broke.
And in that clarity, a quiet peace:
I lived. I loved. I lost.
Rewind life and remember—
then press play,
and live again,
this time with softer eyes.

I dig up grief I buried,

Yet in the ruins, I find treasures:
a hand held in the hospital,

Rewind life and remember—
not to rewrite,

there was beauty.

once remembered,
can light the way forward.

suggesting pause, not statement, in life’s long, dull drama.
I lived in parentheses, a side note, not the line,
my worth conditional, my breath a gift I had to sign
away each day for scraps of worth. I wore a mask of 'fine,'
while underneath, a storm raged—quiet, but malign.
But time, that sculptor of the soul, carved patience in my bones,
and one slow dawn, I noticed how the light through window shone
not on the floor, but higher—on the wall, the shelf, the door.
And I, by habit, looked down first—then lifted, wanting more.
That glance became a habit. Then a stance. Then, finally, a stand.
No thunder, no applause, no hand to lift me from the sand.
Just me. Just will. Just weariness of living on my knees.
And in that quiet rebellion, I found what I could seize:
my voice, my space, my name, my breath—all mine, not earned, not bought,
but born. The creature I once was still flickers in my thought,
but now it’s just a contrast, not a curse. It shows the way
from shadow into sunlight, from decay to light of day.
I was a groveller. Now I walk. Now I face the sun.
Not finished. Not unbroken. But the battle? Well begun.

I bowed to every shadow, scraped my knees on stony pride,

I served with silent footsteps, wore my pain like second skin,
and called it loyalty, called it strength, called anything but sin
against the ones who ruled me. But deep in the quiet core,
a ember glowed, unyielding, whispering, 'There’s more. There’s more.'
Not of power, not of glory, but of self—of being seen
not as a tool, a servant, but a world, a vibrant green
beneath the ash. And slowly, like a bud beneath the snow,
I pushed against the weight above, refused to let it grow
into my heart. I rose—not fast, not tall, not without fear—
but rose, and stood, and whispered, 'I am here. I am here. I am here.'
No thunderclap. No fanfare. Just the sound of breath, of bone
relearning how to carry weight that isn’t all my own.
The creature I once was still hums in the quiet hours,
but now it’s just a memory, not a chain of latent powers.
I walk with head uplifted, not in pride, but in release.
I was a groveller. Now I find my own, unforced, unleased
peace. Not perfect. Not unscarred. But mine. And that is all I need.

instance_metrics.response: People are happy when the sun spills gold on cracked sidewalks, when laughter leaks from open windows like steam from tea kettles. They are happy not because life is easy, but because they remember the taste of bread shared in silence, the weight of a hand on a shoulder during a storm. Happiness here is not a crown, but a pair of worn shoes walking familiar paths. It hums in the rhythm of a broom sweeping dust at dawn, in the way an old man feeds pigeons with crumbs like prayers. People are happy when they stop chasing joy and let it find them—curled in the purr of a cat, hidden in a child’s mispronounced lullaby. It lives in the pause between clock ticks, in the space where breath meets air. Not in palaces, but in porches where neighbors speak without looking up. Not in victories, but in the quiet surrender to what is. People are happy when they forget to measure it. When they plant seeds in tin cans and call it hope. When they name the stars after lost friends and feel them shining back. Happiness is not a destination—it's the gravel under bare feet, the song half-remembered, the soup that’s too salty but still warm.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'People are happy...'

instance_metrics.response: People are happy when the world softens at the edges—when streetlights bloom like dandelions and shadows dance without rhythm. They are happy in stolen moments: a note left on a pillow, a dog’s wet nose nudging a hand, a sudden downpour that ruins plans but births laughter. Happiness is not a fortress but a breeze slipping through ajar doors. It arrives when expectations dissolve—when dinner burns and someone says, 'Let’s eat toast and stargaze instead.' People are happy not despite the cracks, but because of them—the light gets in, and so do they. They are happy in the hum of a refrigerator at midnight, in the crease of a well-read book, in the way a stranger smiles while handing back a dropped glove. It isn’t loud. It doesn’t wear ribbons. It’s the quiet agreement to keep going, to plant marigolds in cracked concrete, to sing off-key in the shower. People are happy when they stop performing joy and simply allow it—like breath, like tide, like the moon that appears whether we look or not. It’s in the courage to say, 'I’m okay,' and mean it, even when 'okay' is all they have. Happiness is not a prize. It’s the hand that holds yours when the wind howls.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'People are happy...'

instance_metrics.response: People are happy when they forget to watch the clock, when hours stretch like cats in sunbeams. They are happy in gardens where weeds grow beside roses, accepting both as kin. Happiness is the steam from a morning cup curling into stories, the way boots kick through autumn leaves without regret. It lives in kitchens where recipes are guessed, in letters never sent but deeply felt. People are happy when they dance alone in living rooms, when they cry without shame, when they admit they don’t know and find peace there. It’s in the weight of a library book, the smell of rain on hot pavement, the echo of a name called down a hallway. Not in perfection, but in the charm of crooked fences and mismatched socks. Happiness is the dog that greets you like you're the sun, the child who draws you with six fingers because love has extra digits. It blooms when we stop asking 'Is this enough?' and whisper 'This is.' People are happy in the pause after a sneeze, in the hum of a fridge, in the way a cat chooses your lap over silk cushions. It is not earned. It is noticed. It’s the quiet hum beneath the noise, the constant star behind clouds. People are happy when they remember they are alive, and alive is a kind of magic.

Happiness is the dog-eared page, the chipped mug that holds the best coffee, the sweater worn thin from hugging. People are happy when they plant seeds they’ll never see grow, when they apologize first, when they laugh at their own jokes. Happiness is the postcard from no one special, the dandelion growing through asphalt, the cat that adopts you at midnight. It’s in the courage to be soft in a world that admires armor. Happiness isn’t a destination with flags and fanfare—it’s the dirt on your knees from gardening, the song you hum without knowing the words, the quiet certainty that you are, somehow, exactly where you’re meant to be.

instance_metrics.response: It snowed and snowed, the whole world over, / Blanketing cities in hush and white. / Roofs bowed low beneath the cover, / And stars forgot their ancient light. / Each flake a whisper from the sky’s deep loom, / Spinning silence through the frayed edges of time. / The rivers paused beneath a glassy tomb, / And mountains wore crowns sublime. / No footstep dared to mar the even sheet, / As if the earth had drawn a breath and stilled. / Beneath, the roots conversed in quiet beat, / While dreams, like embers, softly filled. / The world, once loud with clamor and with speed, / Now lay in thought, a monochrome creed. / And in that hush, a truth began to show— / That stillness holds more music than we know. / The snow did not erase, but rather gave— / A canvas for the souls the earth would save.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'It snowed and snowed ,the whole world over,'

instance_metrics.response: It snowed and snowed, the whole world over, / And time unknit its hurried seams. / The clocks forgot to count, the skies to hover— / Just silver silence in the seams. / A boy built a fortress from frozen breath, / His laughter muffled, sweet and thin. / A fox left lace upon the edge of death, / Where hunger gnawed, but peace crept in. / The church steeple wore a monk’s pale hood, / The river’s song was wrapped in ice. / Even the wind seemed understood / That some things should remain precise. / Not death, but pause. Not end, but dream. / A globe reborn in frost and gleam. / And when the thaw at last would come, / It would carry traces of that quiet hum— / For snow, once fallen, never truly goes: / It lives in how the quiet grows.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'It snowed and snowed ,the whole world over,'

instance_metrics.response: It snowed and snowed, the whole world over, / And memory turned to mist and lace. / Each flake a letter someone tried to cover, / Sent from a forgotten face. / The fields became a page no hand could write, / Except the wind with fleeting script. / Windows wept frost in scrolls of light, / And time slipped, cold-lipped. / A train stood still, a steel-gray ghost, / Its whistle lost in woolen air. / A child drew constellations on the coast / Of breath fogging the stair. / The world was not erased, but redefined— / Not black and white, but thought and shade. / In every drift, a secret mind, / In every hush, a serenade. / For snow does not destroy, it recompenses— / It shows us how the unseen senses.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'It snowed and snowed ,the whole world over,'

instance_metrics.response: It snowed and snowed, the whole world over, / And silence grew thick as wool. / The trees stood like monks in white cloister, / Praying in a frozen pool. / No bird dared pierce the dome of gray, / No car dared hum its usual tune. / Night came early, and stayed to stay, / Beneath a slow, descending moon. / A mother sang to a child asleep, / Her voice a thread through frozen air. / The world outside had gone too deep— / A dream beneath a dream lay bare. / And in that sleep, the earth confessed: / It longed for moments without test. / To not be fertile, warm, or loud, / But wrapped in one soft, shapeless shroud. / Snow is the world’s deep breath released— / The moment peace is not a priest, but priestess.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'It snowed and snowed ,the whole world over,'

instance_metrics.response: It snowed and snowed, the whole world over, / And every border disappeared. / The rich man’s gate, the beggar’s cover— / All smoothed by flakes that knew no fear. / The war paused, not by treaty signed, / But by the weight of white descent. / Hearts, long frozen, were redefined, / As grief and gladness both were bent. / A soldier dropped his rifle in the drift, / A poet found a word long lost. / The snow did not discriminate or lift— / It simply counted every cost. / Not with coin, but with calm and chill, / With absence loud as any drum. / The world stood still upon the hill, / And in that stillness, everyone / Became a child, or became a sage— / Walking a page from a frozen age.

in the cracked palm of a dying land,
where shadows stretch like thirsty hands
and time has turned to brittle sand.

and rainworn stones would softly sing;
now silence hums a hollow hymn
beneath a merciless, bleached-out ring.

holds up the sky like trembling glass—
a moment caught before it fails,
a breath drawn slow, too long to pass.

of sandpipers with urgent wings,
reminds the dust of former light,
and how the chorus used to ring.

The earth remembers what it was—
a cradle lush, a lullaby,
a world that pulsed with secret laws
beneath the sun’s unblinking eye.

And though the waters fade from view,
and roots grow thin from searching deep,
something still waits, unseen, true:
the promise that the rains will leap.

Not now, perhaps, not in this hour,
but in the grammar of the land,
there is a green and rising power
that sleeps, yet answers to command.

Just a few dwindling pools remain—
but in their depth, the world’s refrain.

Before me stands I see a clock with no hands, no face, 
Just gears that turn in silence through time and formless space. 
No past, no future pressing—just now, suspended, deep—
A moment stripped of labels, where even shadows sleep. 
And in the center, pulsing, a heart without a name,

Before me stands I—not as man, nor child, nor sage, 
But essence stripped of stories, the turning of an age. 
It does not speak in language, but in tremors, soft and low, 
A frequency that vibrates through every place I go. 
No need for justification, no guilt, no pride, no test—
Just being, pure and weightless, like breath inside a chest. 
Before me stands I, and the clock dissolves to air—
Not gone, but understood, beyond all thought or prayer.

I walk, not toward water, but toward that distant glow, 
Each step a reckoning with what I’ve come to know. 
Before me stands I—sun-scorched, tired, but unbent, 
A traveler who carries maps of where the soul is sent. 
It offers no illusion, no oasis, no reprieve, 
But shares the weight of walking, the grief the heart must leave. 
And when I reach the lantern, it does not burn, but glows—
A warmth that speaks of journeys where the inner compass grows. 
Before me stands I, and the desert sings its tune—
Not of end, but endless—beneath a harvest moon.

Before me stands I see a violin with strings of rust and gold,

No bow lies near to play it, no score upon the stand,

I lift it to my shoulder, though I’ve long forgot the tune,

Before me stands I—holding not the instrument, but me—

It doesn’t ask for mastery, nor fame, nor grand display, 
But just to hum one note—true—and let the shadows play. 
So I breathe, and in the stillness, a single tone takes flight—
Not perfect, not majestic, but utterly, deeply right. 
Before me stands I, and the music starts to flow—
Not from the strings, but from the place where all my sorrows go.

instance_metrics.response: One dark, dark night—it was long ago, / The clocks all stopped at twenty-one. / I walked a road of glass and snow, / Beneath a sky of dying sun. / A figure stood at miles away, / Wearing my coat, my wedding day. / I called, but sound refused to fly; / The world was muffled, dry as sigh. / When I arrived, the space was bare— / Just footprints leading into air. / A locket lay upon the ground, / Inside, a whisper without sound. / I held it close, and felt it beat, / Like something trapped beneath my feet. / One dark, dark night—it shaped my soul, / And left a hole to make me whole.

instance_metrics.response:
Fire: a scream trapped in wood,
released only when broken.
It hisses with the voice of trees,
of ancient forests turned to coal,
of dinosaurs dreaming in rock.
We strike a match and unseal eons,
let the dead breathe one last blaze.
It flickers like a dying language,
like memories fading from the mind.
We gather around it, as our ancestors did,
sharing silence, soup, sorrow.
No screens, no noise—just flame and face.
And in its glow, we remember
what it means to be small, mortal,
and utterly alive.
Fire doesn’t care about our wars,
our wealth, our names.
It only knows how to burn,
and in that purity, we find peace.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Fire:'

instance_metrics.response:
Fire: the color of warning,
of stop signs, of blood, of rage.
It flares in arguments, in riots,
in the blush of betrayal.
It lives in the chest when injustice strikes,
in the fist when it clenches.
We say, ‘She has fire,’ and mean strength,
but also danger, unpredictability.
Fire does not negotiate;
it consumes, transforms, moves on.
Like revolution, like grief, like love,
it cannot be contained forever.
It will find a crack, a breath, a spark,
and surge into the world again.
So let us not fear the fire within,
but tend it with wisdom,
feed it truth, not lies,
and let it light the way
through the long, cold night of ignorance.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Fire:'

instance_metrics.response:
Fire: not just destruction,
but the quiet glow of a pilot light,
the blue kiss beneath the kettle.
It is the stove where soup simmers,
the candle on a birthday, the flare
in a stranded sailor’s hand.
It is ritual: yule logs, Diwali lamps,
the eternal flame for the fallen.
Fire sanctifies, signals, sustains.
It is the element of ceremony,
of passage, of presence.
To gather around fire is to say,
We are here. We are together.
Even in cities of steel and glass,
we crave its primal pulse.
We build fire pits in backyards,
light fireplaces in summer.
Because deep down, we remember
that fire is not just heat,
but home.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Fire:'

instance_metrics.response:
Fire: a paradox in motion.
It gives light by devouring darkness,
warmth by destroying fuel.
It creates safety by threatening harm.
It is chaos shaped by air,
a storm in miniature.
Watch it long enough, and you’ll swear
it thinks, plans, dreams.
It reaches like a hand, retreats like a ghost,
then surges with sudden fury.
Biologists say we evolved near fire,
that our brains grew larger by its light.
Perhaps consciousness itself
was forged in flame.
Now we project our minds outward—
into code, into space, into art—
all descendants of that first spark.
Fire didn’t just cook our food;
it cooked our minds,
and set them alight.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Fire:'

instance_metrics.response:
Fire: the artist’s first tool.
Not brush, not chisel, but flame.
It glazed the pot, tempered the blade,
fired the kiln where beauty was born.
It blackened the cave wall,
where hands left negative stars.
It turned clay to ceramic,
iron to steel, sand to glass.
Even now, in digital age,
fire hums in the server’s core,
in the smelter, in the welder’s arc.
It is creation’s accomplice,
the hidden hand behind every crafted thing.
We praise the sculptor, the painter,
but forget the fire that made it possible.
So let us honor the flame
not just as destroyer, but maker—
patient, precise, alchemical,
transforming base into brilliance,
ash into art.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Fire:'

instance_metrics.response:
Fire: a heartbeat made visible.
Throbbing, irregular, alive.
It breathes with the wind,
sleeps when starved, wakes when fed.
It has moods—calm, wild, sullen, bright.
It casts moving shadows,
like thoughts across a restless mind.
I watch it to still my own chaos,
to remember that even destruction
has rhythm, grace, purpose.
It does not rush; it unfolds.
Like grief, like healing, like time,
it cannot be forced.
It will burn until it won’t,
then leave only embers,
soft and glowing, like distant stars.

that warmth returns.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Fire:'

instance_metrics.response:
Fire: the element of transformation.
Not water, not earth, not air—
but the one that changes everything it touches.
It turns wood to charcoal,
metal to liquid,

instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Fire:'

instance_metrics.response:
Fire: a language older than words.
Our ancestors read its signs—
height, color, direction of smoke.
A small flame meant safety;
a column of black meant war, or storm.
It warned of beasts, summoned allies,
cooked, cleansed, celebrated.
Now we’ve forgotten how to listen,
but the flame still speaks.
In wildfires, it shouts our neglect.
In candles, it whispers prayer.
In campfires, it hums lullabies.
And if you sit very still,
you might hear it say,
Remember. Return. Revere.
For fire is not yours to own,
but to honor, to learn from,
to let burn when it must,
and to protect from turning
the world to cinder.

through cracks in the pavement,
through songs, through strikes,

of a people who refuse to freeze.

instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Fire:'

instance_metrics.response:

—proof that even when all else fails,

instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Fire:'

instance_metrics.response:
Fire: not an end, but a threshold.
It does not erase, but rewrites.

fertilizer, potential.

don’t curse them.
Stand in the heat.

Then walk forward,
not unscarred, but unafraid.

instance_metrics.response:
Fire: the first magician.

 silence loud with crackle.

fire always says yes.

And as the stars begin to blink,
The train rolls on, on the edge of the brink
Between what was and what may come—
A metal hymn, a beating drum.

instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'You can hear the excitement start to linger as the early morning train departs.'

instance_metrics.response:
We have met before, in whispers of the dawn,
Where light first spills across a sleeping world.
Not in flesh, but in echo—fragments drawn
From dreams where destinies were gently curled.
Perhaps in ancient marketplaces we passed,
You with eyes full of unspoken lore,
I a shadow, fleeting, unsurpassed.
Our breaths once synced upon a distant shore.
Maybe in a garden thick with jasmine scent,
Beneath a moon that bled silver and gold,
Our fingers nearly touched, but time was bent,
And we were pulled apart before we’d hold.
Centuries folded like paper cranes,
Still, I feel the ghost of your hands.
We have met before, in every life I’ve known,
In every loss, in every seed I’ve sown.
Not just in moments, but in the space between,
In silence, in glances, in what might have been.
And when our names dissolve and stars grow cold,
Still, we’ll remember: we have met before.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'We have met before'

instance_metrics.response:
In the hush between heartbeats, I recognized you—
a flicker in the gaslight of memory.
Not in this life, perhaps, but in the blue
aftermath of a century’s debris.
We shared a bench in a forgotten square,
You reading verses I had yet to write.
We’ve met before, in every breath of air,
In every pause before the end of night.
Was it 1843, Paris, late October?
You wore a coat the color of stormy seas.
Or Venice, drowning beneath a fever,
Our love a secret the canals could not keep.
We’ve been poets, thieves, ghosts in a play,
Lovers severed on some ancient stage.
Even now, as I turn and walk away,
Your voice lingers on the edge of age.
We have met before, and will again,
in constellations stitched with silent pain.
Across dimensions, through the veil’s thin door,
Our souls keep whispering: we have met before.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'We have met before'

instance_metrics.response:
We have met before—beneath the elm
where autumn leaves recite old names,
where silence wears a human helm,
and time forgets to play its games.
Not in a ballroom, nor a train,
but where the river hums its hymn,
where moonlight writes in silver stain
the truth we never dared to trim.
I saw you first in someone else’s dream,
a cameo etched in twilight’s core.
You called my name without a scream,
and I recalled what came before.
We were birds that never learned to land,
winged through lifetimes, never still.
You, a scar upon my hand;
me, the ache inside your will.
We’ve loved, we’ve warred, we’ve changed our skins,
met in battles, danced in rain.
Even now, as history thins,
I feel your pulse against my brain.
We have met before, and so it stands:
the universe repeats with knowing hands.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'We have met before'

instance_metrics.response:
We have met before—in smoke and glass,
where mirrors warp but cannot lie.
You stepped from shadows, slow and vast,
with storms behind your clouded eye.
Not in a city, not in spring,
but in the pause before a fall,
where every broken thing takes wing,
and silence learns to call.
I knew you by the way you weep,
not loud, but deep, like tectonic groans.
By how you hold the promises you keep,
and bury keys inside your bones.
We’ve stood in line at Judgment’s gate,
both guilty, both absolved, both scarred.
We played at gods, we sealed our fate,
and lost each other, star by star.
Yet here you are, in coffee steam,
in subway glances, fleeting, true.
A ghost, a hope, a half-remembered dream—
but I know now: I’ve known you.
We have met before, and though it's odd,
my soul still greets you like an old, old god.

Humidity: thick with unshed tears, clinging to the hem of every passing cloud. Today: isolated explosions possible—these are not meteorological, but inherited. The sun rises, indifferent, gilding the rubble of a school that once taught geography. Now, the only maps are the ones drawn in dust by crawling infants. Forecast calls for a cold front moving in from the north—emotional, not climatic. It brings snow, yes, but also the weight of absence. In the Qala-e-Fatullah district, a woman reads the weather in the way her tea cools too fast—sign of descending sorrow. But then: a sudden break in the clouds. Laughter from a courtyard. Children chasing a deflated soccer ball like it’s a comet. Tomorrow: gusts of memory, chance of dreams. No storm can erase the constellations. Weather Forecast in Kabul: variable skies, steady heart. Scattered resilience, with a chance of miracles. Because even here, after all, the stars still align over the Hindu Kush, silent and certain as prayer.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Weather Forecast in Kabul.'

instance_metrics.response: Weather Forecast in Kabul: today, the clouds are made of old letters, never sent. They drift above the city like ghosts of intention. The wind hums a lullaby in a language only the mountains remember. Sunlight filters through like a rumor—fragile, fleeting. In the Darulaman district, a broken clock tower still casts a shadow, measuring time in defiance. Humidity: measured in the silence between heartbeats when a siren wails. There will be no rain, but the pavement glistens with oil and memory. Forecast: isolated moments of beauty—children drawing on walls with chalk, a flute playing where a bomb once fell. Night brings stars that refuse to be censored, mapping ancient myths over modern ruins. Tomorrow: increasing warmth from human touch, with a chance of shared bread. The real forecast isn’t on any screen. It’s in the way a boy flies a kite made of plastic and string, defying gravity and grief. Weather Forecast in Kabul: unpredictable, but not unforgiving. Because even in the harshest climate, life insists on color. On song. On the quiet certainty that after the longest night, the horizon still blushes with light.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Weather Forecast in Kabul.'

instance_metrics.response: Weather Forecast in Kabul: today, the sky is a fractured mirror. Each shard reflects a different truth—sunlight on a mosque dome, shadow in a crater, a child’s face lit by candlelight. Winds are restless, flipping through pages of forgotten textbooks left in gutted schools. The sun rises with hesitation, as if asking permission. Humidity: measured in the dampness of cheeks after a lullaby. There will be no official warning for the storm that breaks in a mother’s chest when she hears her son’s name called. In the old quarter, a calligrapher writes the word ‘peace’ in flowing script, though he knows it may never come. But he writes it anyway. Forecast: isolated moments of grace—laughter in a marketplace, a shared apple, a dog sleeping in a patch of sun. Night brings a sky so dense with stars it feels like the universe is watching. Tomorrow: increasing clarity, with a chance of dreams spoken aloud. The real forecast is in the way a girl ties her scarf in the wind—bright, unafraid. Weather Forecast in Kabul: not just weather. It’s the atmosphere of endurance, the climate of memory. Winds of change, blowing slow but steady. Forecast: partly broken, fully alive. With a 100% chance of tomorrow.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Weather Forecast in Kabul.'

instance_metrics.response:
In shadows cast by parting light,
Where silence hums a hollow tune,
We find the seeds of quiet growth—
Loss, an unexpected boon.

The tree that sheds its autumn leaves
Does not grieve its fading gold,
But trusts the roots beneath the frost
Will birth a springtime yet untold.

A friendship gone, a love withdrawn,
A dream dissolved in morning mist—
These hollows carved by sorrow’s hand
Are vessels where the soul adjusts.

For comfort rarely schools the heart
In depths where wisdom takes its stand.
It is absence, cold and vast,
That teaches us to understand.

The cracked bowl holds the sweeter rain,
The mended pot, a golden seam—
Kintsugi whispers through the pain:
Some beauty wakes when loss is dreamt.

So let the tides recede with grace,
Leave shells upon the empty shore.
Even in lack, a gift takes place—
We learn to love what’s worth fighting for.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Loss can be good for us,'

instance_metrics.response:
When doors shut fast with thunderous sound,
And echoes mock what once was near,
The soul, at first, falls to the ground,
Beneath the weight of vanished years.

But in that hush, a voice takes root—
Not loud, but steady, soft, and deep—
It says, 'You’re freer in this void,
Than in the arms you had to keep.'

For clinging hands can chain the wings,
And comfort dull the edge of thought.
Loss strips the paint from false imaginings,
And leaves the truth that can’t be bought.

The child who loses bedtime songs
May learn to hum a braver tune.
A heart unmoored from steady throngs
Can navigate by stars alone.

The artist finds her boldest hue
Only after color fails.
The saint is born when prayers feel through,
And heaven seems to close its veils.

So let the old world burn and fade—
From ash, a keener vision grows.
Loss is not a funeral made,
But fertile ground where insight flows.

instance_metrics.response:
A shattered cup upon the floor,
Its fragments gleaming, sharp, and clear—
You mourn the function, crave once more
The warmth of tea held, year on year.

Yet in its broken, scattered form,
New patterns rise with fractured grace.
You sweep with mindful, tender charm,
And see the beauty in its place.

For loss, though cloaked in grief and tear,
Unveils dimensions once concealed.
The things we lose draw near, draw dear,
When absence makes the heart revealed.

The path we walked is overgrown,
But through the thorns, a new trail bends.
The love we knew has overthrown
The need to pretend, to pretend.

We stretch beyond what we possessed,
Expand in spaces left behind.
What vanished taught us how to rest,
And how to reframe peace of mind.

The empty chair, the silent phone,
Are not just voids of what has passed.
They’re altars where the soul has grown,
And wisdom rises from the ash.

instance_metrics.response:
They say that joy is life’s true guide,
A compass bright, a golden thread.
Yet loss, in silence, walks beside,
And shapes the person we become, instead.

The mountain sheds its ancient stone,
Not from weakness, but release.
The forest burns, yet seeds are sown
In charcoal fields, in sudden peace.

A parent’s hand once clasped so tight,
Now gone, yet still its lessons stay.
Their absence fuels a fiercer light—
We live their dreams in different ways.

The job that vanished, dream undone,
May pivot us to truer call.
The lover lost beneath the sun
Unlocks a self we never saw.

For comfort breeds a gentle sleep,
But sorrow wakes the inner eye.
It carves the channels where we leap
To depths we’d never dare to try.

So when the world contracts in pain,
And shadows stretch without reply,
Remember—every loss, a gain
In disguise, beneath the sky.

instance_metrics.response:
When winter grips the trembling bough,
And every leaf has fled the stem,
The tree stands stripped, but not bowed—
It saves its strength for springtime’s hymn.

In loss, the soul finds hidden rooms,
Expanses where the noise once was.
We hear the pulse beneath the gloom,
The quiet truth behind the cause.

The friend who left, the door now shut,
Cleared space for voices more aligned.
The dream that died, though deeply cut,
Freed energy for newer kind.

We are not whole because we hold,
But because we learn to let.
Each loss, a story to be told
In wisdom’s slowly kindling net.

Like rivers shaped by missing stone,
Our currents shift, adapt, and grow.
The heart, once fractured, stands alone,
Yet beats with rhythms it didn’t know.

So grieve, yes—weep, but also see:
The wound is where the light gets in.
And loss, though bitter, sets us free
To rise, anew, beneath the skin.

instance_metrics.response:
The clock unwinds, the hands retreat,
A moment gone, a breath withdrawn.
We clutch the ghost of what was sweet,
And curse the coming of the dawn.

But in the hollows carved by time,
Where echoes of goodbye still ring,
New constellations start to climb,
And different songs the spirit sing.

For ease can lull the soul to sleep,
And plenty blind the seeing eye.
But loss, though harsh, will dig so deep

The artist paints with darker shade
To make the gold stand bold and bright.
The sailor, lost, begins to trade
Old maps for stars that pierce the night.

The lover, severed from their match,
May find a love they’ve never known—
One born not from another’s latch,
But from the seeds they’ve sown alone.

So let the old world fall away.
Let silence speak. Let embers glow.
Loss is the price we pay
To let our truest selves upgrow.

A garden pruned in early spring,
Though wounded, blooms with fiercer grace.
The gardener knows what shears will bring
More blossoms in the growing space.

So too with loss—though harsh, though raw,
It cuts the tangle, clears the way.
We mourn the life we thought we saw,
But find the strength we thought would fray.

The job that slipped, the love that fled,
The voice no longer on the line—
Each absence writes a different thread
Into the fabric of design.

For comfort can be quiet jail,
A gilded cage of soft routine.
But loss, like wind through brittle sail,
Awakens what has long been seen.

The child who loses childhood’s nest
Must grow the wings to leave the ground.
The heart that's been denied its rest
Will learn a deeper, truer sound.

So do not fear the vanishing.
Do not curse the empty chair.
Loss is the art of reshaping
What we carry, what we dare.

instance_metrics.response: In the hush where shadows dwell, / Where silence sings its lullaby too well, / There blooms a truth, both sharp and wise: / Loss can be good for us, in disguise. / Not every end is barren ground— / Some seeds are sown when love is drowned. / A door once shut reveals a window pane, / Through which new light begins to rain. / We prune the trees so they may grow, / And let old rivers change their flow. / What leaves us hollow also makes us deep, / Awakens rhythms we were meant to keep. / Grief, that sculptor with tender hands, / Chisels grace from shifting sands. / We lose a voice, yet find our own— / A self once buried now fully shown. / The heart, though cracked, lets in the dawn. / In letting go, we’re drawn on. / So when the ache feels vast and wide, / Recall the tide must recede to glide. / For loss, though cloaked in sorrow’s hue, / Is often wisdom dressed anew.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Loss can be good for us,'

instance_metrics.response: When the clock unwinds its thread, / And all we love lies cold and dead, / The world may whisper, “This is wrong,” / But listen close—it sings a song. / Loss can be good for us, though slow, / Like winter teaching seeds to grow. / It strips the bark to fortify, / And dims the sun so stars draw nigh. / We think the wound will never mend, / Yet through the tear, new strength extends. / The ship that sank revealed the shore, / The locked door hid a secret door. / We shed our skin to feel the air, / And mourn the mask to find we’re there. / What’s taken shapes the space we need, / A garden grown from what we bleed. / Not all that falls is meant to stay— / Some roots grow deep in disarray. / So let the tempest have its way; / It clears the sky for brighter day. / For every end, a breath begins— / Loss carves room for who we’ve been… and who we might become within.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Loss can be good for us,'

instance_metrics.response: Beneath the ash, the phoenix stirs, / Not born of fire, but from what occurs / When everything we cling to burns— / A lesson loss in silence earns. / It strips the false, the frail, the feigned, / And leaves the soul both scarred, unchained. / For comfort breeds a gentle rust; / It’s loss that forces us to trust— / Not in what was, but what can be, / A self not shaped by memory, / But forged in absence, in the void, / Where echoes teach a voice deployed. / We lose a hand, but learn to write; / We lose the sun, but meet the night. / And in that dark, a map appears— / The constellation of our fears, / Now stars that guide, not haunt, our way. / Loss is the price of seeing day. / It hollows out a sacred space / Where grace can find its resting place. / So when the world goes still and dim, / Don’t curse the vanishing of him, or her, or them. / For in the gap, the self takes root— / Loss can be good, though bitter, mute.

instance_metrics.response: They said the world ended that day— / When you walked out and took the sun away. / But slowly, seasons taught me how / To see the stars I’d never allowed. / Loss can be good for us, though cruel, / A surgeon cutting out the fool / Who clung to comfort, false and sweet, / Now forced to walk on unshod feet. / The wound, though raw, lets air inside, / Where healing hums and truths reside. / We think we lose when love departs, / But gain the courage to restart. / The tree that falls feeds the soil; / The broken vessel holds new oil. / What’s gone was never meant to stay— / Just scaffolding for who we are today. / The heart, once tethered, learns to soar; / The self, once hidden, knocks the door. / Grief is the midwife of the real, / The ache that makes the spirit heal. / Not every gift comes wrapped in joy— / Some come disguised as time’s alloy. / So when the storm has claimed its due, / And left you standing, bruised and blue, / Know this: the ground is rich with dust— / Loss is the seed, and trust the trust.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Loss can be good for us,'

instance_metrics.response: Once I wept for what had fled— / The voice, the touch, the warm bread / Of presence, daily, soft, and near. / Now I see: that loss cleared fear. / For when the anchor slipped away, / I learned to drift, then find my way. / Loss can be good for us, it’s true— / Not kind, not gentle, but it grew / A strength I never knew was mine, / A rhythm beneath the thinnest line. / It stripped the stage of borrowed roles, / And left me bare, composing souls. / The wound, though deep, became a well, / Where silence taught me how to tell / The difference ‘tween what I need / And what I thought would plant the seed. / Some gardens grow in scorched terrain— / Beauty reborn from endless rain. / The love that left was never wrong— / It just outlived its needed song. / And in the quiet, I arose, / Not healed, but whole in different clothes. / So if you grieve, don’t curse the cost— / Loss is the bridge from what was lost… to what was always meant to be, / A truer self, wild, brave, and free.

instance_metrics.response: The moon does not mourn the sun’s retreat, / Nor summer weep when winter’s fleet. / They turn, they shift, they yield, they fall— / Each loss a prelude to a call. / So too the heart, when love departs, / Feels shattered shards and broken parts. / Yet in the cracks, the light gets in, / Not as before, but deep within. / Loss can be good for us, though slow, / A teacher cloaked in winds that blow. / It strips the mask, the guise, the show, / And bids the real self rise and grow. / We think we die when dreams collapse, / But often, that’s the soul’s true maps. / The job, the love, the friend, the plan— / Their end reveals the deeper span. / For every no, a yes takes root; / For every fruit, a fallen shoot. / The self expands in empty rooms, / Where silence hums familiar tunes. / Not all that dies is truly gone— / Some live as strength when day is drawn. / So when the world feels stripped and thin, / Remember: loss lets new life in. / It clears the soil, it thins the vine— / Loss is the pruning hand of time.

It slipped away. / But in its wake, I found my play. / The friend who left? A mirror cracked— / Reflected parts I’d long factored. / We lose to gain, we fall to rise, / We close our eyes to recognize / The self beneath the borrowed name, / The fire born of silent flame. / Not every wound is meant to heal— / Some teach the soul how real feels. / Loss is the tide that clears the shore, / Makes space for gifts we didn’t know before. / It breaks the shell so life can breathe, / Lets sorrow plant what joy can’t reach. / So when the storm has had its say, / Don’t curse the night—just watch the gray / Turn gold, as dawn, on tender feet, / Proves loss and love are bittersweet.

Beneath the gables where the ivy clings,
Where chalk-dust ghosts of lessons past still rise,
Three shadows dart on ancient courtyard wings,
Like foxes lit by moon in sly disguise.
Boys with the glint of mischief in their stare,
Plotting in hushed tones beneath elm trees,
The air is thick with secrets in the air,
And laughter tangled in the autumn breeze.
No hymn, no rule, no master’s stern command,
Can quench the fire of wit they’ve learned to wield;
Each prank, a sonnet scrawled by unseen hand,
Each dare, a stanza on the battlefield.
This is no childhood idyll, soft and sweet—
It’s war in tweed, with gum and treacle, neat.
A prelude hums, low in the dormitory walls,
Of futures forged in laughter, thumps, and squalls.

In a circus under moonlit skies,
Where stars blink slow with curious eyes,

Forgotten by clocks and calendars too,
A trick that makes grown men cry and undo.

Tents ripple like skin in electric breeze,
While elephants dream of climbing trees,
And acrobats leap through rings of ice
That sing in voices not quite precise.

A child gasps as the lion tamer
Rides a comet through a midnight grammar,
Syntax unraveling in golden thread,
Where meaning dances, half-dead, half-alive instead.

This is no mere parade of oddities,
But wonder spun from anxieties—
The thrill that prickles down your spine,
The sacred new, the borderline.

Where laughter trembles on the edge of fear,
And every marvel feels too near,
We find the truth in what we dread:
In novelty’s thrill, the soul is bared and led.

So step right up, don’t turn away—
The show begins at break of day,
Where every gasp, each startled breath,
Is life reborn—defying death.

On the edge of town, where streetlights fade,
A carnival hums in lemonade shade.
Its banner reads in cursive flame:
‘Hair-raising novelty—come, play the game.’

You enter through a mouth of fog,
Where mirrors twist your dog into a frog,
And laughter echoes, sharp and thin,
Like violin strings pulled from within.

A fortune teller, made of glass,
Predicts your death in molasses,
Yet winks and says, ‘But first, delight—
Behold the man who swallows night.’

He rises on a thread of smoke,
His skin a map of ancient jokes,
And as he chokes down shadows whole,
Your scalp begins to lose control.

This isn’t magic, nor mere trick—
It’s novelty with psychic kick,
A jolt that stirs the primal core,
Like thunder cracking at the door.

You leave with coins that melt by dawn,
And dreams that speak in backward yawn.
Yet still you grin, though chilled, amazed:
For wonder, once ignited, stays.

Hair-raising novelty—it’s not just show,
But proof that we still dare to grow,
To feel the fear, then laugh, and say:
‘Let’s do it all again someday.’

Hair-raising novelty—
a key that fits no lock,
yet opens every door
when placed against the shock
of expectation. It hums,
a frequency unseen,
that rattles bone and memory,
and paints the in-between.
A painting that repaints itself
each time you turn away,
its colors drawn from dreams you’ve lost
at dawn’s insistent gray.
A poem that refuses end,
its stanzas multiply,
with verses written in a tongue
that doesn’t justify.
This novelty—it crawls,
like spiders made of light,
across the skin of certainty,
dissolving day and night.
We twitch, we blink, we question
if we’ve slept too long,
but in that twitch, that moment,
we’ve already moved along.
For progress is not gentle;
it’s a jolt, a sudden flame—
the world reborn in static,
whispering each name.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Hair-raising novelty;'

instance_metrics.response:
Hair-raising novelty—
a gust from outer space,
that slips beneath the skin
and rearranges face
and thought and memory.
It’s not a thing to hold,
but something that holds you,
in circuits bright and bold.
A tree that grows in seconds,
its branches made of sound,
its roots in quantum foam,
its fruit a falling crown.
A city where the walls
are built from human breath,
and streets are paved with silence,
and buildings dance with death.
This novelty—it tingles,
a rash of pure surprise,
the itch beneath the surface
of familiar skies.
We scratch, we laugh, we panic,
but cannot look away,
for what is new and shuddering
might just be here to stay.
Not soft, not sweet, not gentle,
but electric, raw, and vast—
the future’s jagged fingerprint
pressed into the past.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Hair-raising novelty;'

instance_metrics.response:
Hair-raising novelty—
a ripple in the known,
like fingers down the spine
of something overgrown
with habit, rust, and rule.
It stirs the sleeping wire,
the synapse long unused,
and sets the mind on fire.
A mirror made of water
that reflects a different face—
your own, but not your own,
with time erased from space.
A clock that ticks in colors,
its hands a hummingbird,
measuring not minutes,
but the weight of every word.
This novelty—it crawls,
like ants on naked skin,
but not to bite or harm,
just let the new begin.
We flinch, we gasp, we wonder
if this is real or dream,
but in the trembling silence,
nothing stays as it did seem.
For innovation isn’t neat;
it’s wild, it’s raw, it’s stark—
the universe reminding us:
‘You’re standing in the dark.’

instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Hair-raising novelty;'

instance_metrics.response:
Go, go, my naughty girl, and kiss
the wind where shadows twist and hiss,
where moonlight spills on silent grass
and time forgets the morrow’s mass.
Run barefoot through the midnight dew,
a comet’s spark, a sapphire hue.
Steal breath from stars and name them true,
write sonnets in the sky’s vast blue.
But if you tire, and stumble slow,
let silence sing what hearts best know.
Return not with a crown of gold,
but stories of the brave and bold—
of dragons tamed with lullabies,
of oceans crossed on butterfly wings.
Go, go, my love, both fierce and curled,
unravel dreams in this wide world.
And when you’ve kissed the edge of night,
return to me, my soul’s delight.
For every kiss you dare to give
is one I cherish, one I live.
So go, my girl, both wild and wise,
with laughter bright in dancing eyes.
Yet know, wherever paths may twirl,
my love remains: the silent girl.

instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'refreshing dawn mist, crisp air'

instance_metrics.response:
Busy old fool, unruly Sun, why dost thou run,
Through fields of time, disturbing those in love?
Must all the world obey your ancient gun,
That fires hours like arrows from above?
Thou call'st the schoolboy late, the sour prentice done,
And rousest traders to schemes they’re dreaming of.
Thou fool, we part not by your golden gun,
For love knows neither night nor morn’s rough shove.

Our world’s a bed—no need for your beams,
Which peep through curtains like a tipsy spy.
Love is a sphere where daylight dims, it seems,
And time dissolves when two souls intertie.
Thy duties? Chide late schoolboys, warm up bees,
But leave us—lovers make their own sunrise.

We are the epicenter of all light,
No borrowed radiance from your tired face.
In each kiss, we eclipse your might,
And in our sighs, you find your trace.
Go, tell those who value gold and gain
That we possess a sun none can reclaim.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Busy old fool, unruly Sun,'

instance_metrics.response:
Busy old fool, unruly Sun, with robes of flame unfurled,
Must you crash our quiet world, a herald of the day?
We were wrapped in dreams unborn, two souls in whispered turn,
And now you rip the veil and steal our gentle play.

Do farmers need you? Let them curse the dew,
Let courtiers bow to clocks, let merchants chase the hour.
But we, who love beyond the scope of what is true,
Defy your reign with every whispered power.

Our bed is compassed by desire, a sphere no clock can span,
Where minutes melt like wax beneath a lover’s tongue.
You govern tides and seasons, yes, but not the human plan
Of hearts that speak in silence, where time is overcome.

So go—chase shadows on sundials, warm the frost,
Command the larks, but leave our midnight sun.
For in our arms, the universe is lost,
And born again when two become as one.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Busy old fool, unruly Sun,'

instance_metrics.response:
Busy old fool, unruly Sun, with molten tongue and glare,
Why burst upon our chamber like a thief of sleep?
We, tangled in a world no daylight dares to share,
Had built a universe where only whispers creep.

You think your beams control the rhythm of the earth?
That farmers rise because you blink your golden eye?
We’ve forged a realm beyond your reach, of infinite rebirth,
Where lovers orbit like twin stars across the sky.

One drop of her perfume outweighs your blazing crown,
A sigh from him outshines your fiercest noon.
You warm the soil, but we—our passion melts it down,
And in our breath, new seasons bloom too soon.

So go, illuminate the dull, the blind, the cold,

They danced on waves like thoughts across the mind, fleeting, bright, and tinged with melancholy. No single helm could claim the wind confined, yet all obeyed the moon’s pale sovereignty. Some bore the weight of kingdoms turned to dust, their holds packed tight with relics, bones, and blame. Others, mere rafts of dreams and morning trust, drifted toward no city, no fixed name. One carried laughter frozen into glass, another bore a symphony half-sung. They passed like glances in a crowded mass, each lonely, each a universe unsung. For in that tiny vessel, free and rare, they saw what sailing truly could have been: not conquest, trade, or terror in the air, but peace—a dance with water, sky, and wind.

Sailors say its glow can be seen, alone, on nights when truth is hardest to abide.

Breath when sheathed by the web of ebbs,
A whisper caught in tidal scripts,
Where moonlight writes and ocean thins,
And silence folds in coral lips.

The lungs become a hollow cove,
Inhaling dusk, exhaling dove—
Not flight, but drift, a silvered glide
Through brine-born dreams where stars subside.

The deep’s grammar in currents spread.

While drowned constellations weep

Their light in pulses, faint and frail,

Breath, once bold, now bound and bent,

Sheathed not by steel, but silt and sway,
It pulses—soft—a muted play
Of life that wears the ocean’s gown,
And speaks in ripples, never sound.

So let the web entwine and press,
This breath a hymn of stillness. Yes—
In ebb there sings a lullaby,
A love note etched where currents sigh.

instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Breath  when sheathed by the web of ebbs'

instance_metrics.response:
I always see to it—
the kettle sings its silver song,
the windows wear their morning light like lace,
and dust does not settle on the photograph of you.

I always see to it
that the flowers in the blue vase
are changed before their heads bow in surrender,
that the clock keeps its steady, ticking promise,
and the door is never locked against return.

I whisper chores into the ears of silence,
fold laundry with the precision of a vow,
press each crease like a memory made tangible.
Even the moon, when it slips through the blinds,
finds its path unobstructed.

I always see to it
that your teacup waits,
rim unchipped, handle aligned south,
filled only with the ghost of steam.

And when the night thickens,
and the house breathes in its wooden sleep,
I still see to it—
that the light in the hall
is low, but never out.

For to stop seeing to it
is to admit you’re gone,
and I have made a life
of not admitting.

So I see to it.
I always see to it.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'i always see to it'

instance_metrics.response:
I always see to it—the garden remembers,
even in winter, the shape of your footsteps.
Snow drapes the rosemary like unspoken vows,
but beneath the frost, the bulbs rehearse their return.

I always see to it
that the bench by the gate stays unpainted,
its splinters proof of time, not neglect.
Your initials still nest in the wood’s soft grain,
and I run my thumb over them each dusk,
like a mantra carved by weather and waiting.

I train the ivy away from the porch light,
though it strains toward brightness like grief
strains toward resolution.
I always see to it
that the light burns—
a small defiance against the swallowing dark.

Even the wind knows my routine:
how I straighten the wind chimes,
how I leave the back door ajar
just wide enough for a shadow to slip through.

I always see to it
that hope is not housed in words,
but in the tending—the watering, the pruning,
the refusal to let stillness claim the soil.

And if one day you do not return,
the garden will have known first,
its roots coiled tight with the truth:
I always see to it,
even when seeing feels like believing
in a future that never arrives.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'i always see to it'

instance_metrics.response:
I always see to it
that the stars are inventoried each night—
Orion’s belt still three bright eyes,
the Plough still tilted, pouring nothing.

I always see to it
that the radio plays your favorite hour,
static smoothed into melody,
and the kettle lifts its voice
on the precise second you once called perfect.

I keep the left shoe by the door,
laces untied, as if mid-step.
The coat hangs in the hall,
dusty with absence, yet aired every Tuesday.

I always see to it
that silence is not mistaken for emptiness.
I feed it sugar in tea,
speak to it like a guest who overstays,
but never leaves.

The calendar tears itself down,
but I stitch the pages back
for days you might still claim.

I always see to it
that the world runs on the rhythm of your breath,
even though I no longer feel it
on the nape of my neck.

The universe hums a different tune,
but I tune my ears to the old frequency.

Because to stop seeing to it
is to let the machinery of memory stall.

So I oil the hinges of habit,
wind the clock of routine,
and whisper into the void:
I always see to it,
I always see to it,
I always see to it.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'i always see to it'

instance_metrics.response:
I always see to it
that the coffee is brewed at 7:03,
not a second sooner, never later.
The mug—chipped rim, sunflower faded to ghost-yellow—
sits at the corner of the table,
handle turned east, as if guiding the sun.

I always see to it
that the birds are fed,
even when their songs feel like accusations.
The breadcrumbs are scattered in a spiral,
a labyrinth leading nowhere,
but they come anyway, hungry for ritual.

I dust the piano keys,
though no one plays.
Middle C still sings when pressed,
a note that trembles like a question.
I always see to it
that it’s pressed at least once a day.

The mailbox is checked twice,
though the letters stopped coming years ago.
Still, I smooth the flag down,
align the latch just so,
in case hope arrives in an envelope
with no return address.

I always see to it
that the porch light flickers at dusk,
a stuttering beacon for ghosts or moths.
Maybe both.

And when the wind carries a voice
that almost sounds like yours,
I don’t turn. I don’t breathe.
I always see to it
that the moment lasts
just one second longer
than it should.

Because seeing to it
is the only way I know
how to keep loving you
without an object.

I always see to it.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'i always see to it'

instance_metrics.response:
I always see to it
that the ocean is remembered inland.
I fill the sink too full,
let the water tremble at the rim,
then still—like tide caught in hesitation.

I always see to it
that salt stays within reach:
on my tongue, in the air I pretend to taste,
in the tears I don’t call by name.

The map on the wall is never rolled up.
Your route—imagined, invented, insisted—
still glows beneath my fingertip,
the dotted line pulsing like a vein.

I always see to it
that the windows face east,
that the first light strikes the floorboards
where your shadow might first land.

I speak to the echo in the bathtub,
scrub the tiles until they shine like wet stone.
I always see to it
that water is never still.

Even the rain is welcomed,
its rhythm a Morse code I pretend to read.
I answer in hushed syllables,
keeping time with the downpour.

I always see to it
that the horizon exists
even when clouds swallow the sky.
I draw it in steam on the mirror,
trace it with a finger
that trembles like a compass needle.

And if you never return,
the sea will not forget you.
Neither will I.

I always see to it.

I always see to it
that the silence has furniture.
A chair by the window. A blanket folded.

which I call your favorite station.

I always see to it
that the air smells of cinnamon and absence,
that the floorboards creak in the old pattern,
the one that spelled your name in Morse long ago.

I leave the back gate unlatched,
though the weeds have grown like guards.
The path is overgrown,
but I walk it daily, clearing space
for a footfall that may never come.

I always see to it
that the teapot sings a single, sustained note—
the one you said sounded like longing
with perfect pitch.

I speak to the empty coat on the hook,
adjust its collar, whisper the weather.
I always see to it
that it’s prepared for rain.

At night, I leave a light burning
in the room you never slept in.
I call it your room anyway,
and keep it cold,
so your breath would still fog the glass.

I always see to it
that love is not a verb in the past tense.
It is a task list, a routine, a silent oath:
feed the silence, water the absence,
keep the world hospitable for a ghost.

Because I always see to it
that you could come home
and find everything
exactly as it was
the moment you left.

I always see to it.

Not for pills, but for patience;
Not for cures, but for curiosity.

Now when I have a cold, I speak in Morse code—
Sniff. Sniff pause. Sniff-sniff. (That means: *I miss you.*)
My nose, a faulty radio, only tunes to static and sorrow.
I wrap myself in blankets like bandages,
As if warmth could suture the space between breaths.
Each cough a telegram from the depths: *Danger. Proceed with care.*
I watch the clock in slow motion,
Each minute a mile through mud.
But in this quarantine of the self,
I hear the quiet hum of love:
A text: *How are you?*
A dropped meal at the door,
Steam still rising like a ghost of care.
Now when I have a cold, I learn
That illness is not just absence of health,
But presence of something else—
A chance to be held, not for what I do,
But for the simple act of breathing,
Even when it hurts.
Even when it sounds like a broken accordion.

Now when I have a cold, I write haiku in my head:

Snot on tissue art.
Steam rises. Cat watches. Soup
Forgets to be eaten.

I count the seconds
Between coughs. One. Two. Three. Four. Five.
Life in fragments now.

Blanket fortress high.
Outside, the world spins on. I
Am planet of rest.

Now when I have a cold,
I speak in syllables,
In pauses, in sighs.

The kettle sings koto,
A Japanese lullaby
For the ailing West.

I don’t need epics.
Just this: a warm hand on my brow,
And silence after sneeze.

Illness teaches form—
How beauty lives in limits,
In the small, the slow, the now.

not words, but colors:

Well. Whole. Distant.

Now when I have a cold, I stop pretending

Butchered, beautiful.
I let the metaphors carry me,
Until the fever breaks,

I’m hosting a tiny tyrant,

Dear Love,
Your voice is honey on my throat.
Your soup, a sacrament. Stay near,
Even if I can’t speak.

Dear Body,
I know I push you hard.
Now, in this forced pause,
I see your strength—
How you fight, how you endure,
How you still breathe,
Even when it hurts.

Now when I have a cold, I learn
That love doesn’t need speeches.
Sometimes, it’s a text.
A dropped meal.
A silence that says: *I’m here.*
And that is enough.

instance_metrics.response: How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth, / Stolen the bloom that graced my morning sky. / The gilded dreams of reckless, restless truth / Now fade like stars the waking world pass by. / No drum, no cry—theft came on silent feet, / A shadowed breath upon my nape of pride. / What once was bold now falters, bittersweet, / As years, like leaves, in quiet corners hide. / Yet in this loss, a quieter fire grows— / Not bright with youth, but deep with gathered lore. / The mirror shows not what the spirit owes, / But maps of storms I wandered, sought, and bore. / Though Time has stripped the petals from the stem, / My roots run deep where no thief follows them. / I name the hours, not as loss, but gain— / Each wrinkle, wisdom wearing light as rain.
